author: Sonia Haria
title: The make-up artists to follow for London Fashion Week
text:
The make-up artists to follow for London Fashion Week Credit: REX/REX Sonia Haria , Beauty Editor 16 February 2017 • 12:22pm 
A hh, Instagram is such a joy for beauty. No sooner has a make-up artist slicked a line of kohl across a model’s eye that we know the exact look of the show via social media. From the lipstick used at Burberry to the eyeshadow donned at Prada, you can feel like you’re backstage with a click of an app. Boy do we love 21st century technology. 
Here is your list of our favourite make-up artists to follow ahead of London Fashion Week (get cracking guys, it’s only a mere few days away). Pat McGrath on @patmcgrathreal A post shared by Pat McGrath (@patmcgrathreal) on Oct 17, 2015 at 10:21am PDT 
A n early adopter of backstage Instagramming, Ms McGrath is one to get on your radar, like, right now. She does so many of the top shows, from Prada to Dolce & Gabbana, creating the look of the season. Last September, she even unveiled swatches of her first ever product, a multi-purpose gold shimmer powder. Safe to say we’re expecting big things this season, Pat. No pressure. Lynsey Alexander on @lynseyalexander A post shared by Lynsey Alexander (@lynseyalexander) on Oct 1, 2016 at 3:43am PDT 
T here are many strings to Lynsey Alexander's bow. She's Estee Lauder's UK make-up ambassador, she's creates incredible looks for both the catwalk and for ad campaigns, and she still managing to squeeze in plenty of horse-riding. She's worth following to get a real insight into life as a make-up artist, and most importantly, how to make it work for you. Diane Kendal on @diane.kendal A post shared by Diane Kendal (@diane.kendal) on Feb 13, 2017 at 10:31am PST 
D iane Kendal has one of the most impressive portfolios and yet she has a relatively small profile compared to other make-up artists. She's famous for creating that 'real' looking skin and using product sparingly. Expect to see Kendal's work across New York, London, Milan and Paris. Wendy Rowe on @wendyrowe A post shared by Wendy Rowe (@wendyrowe) on Sep 19, 2016 at 2:55pm PDT 
T he lead make-up artist for Burberry, Wendy Rowe paints the faces of all the coolest cats on the block including Cara and Suki. Follow her for close-up of iconic Burberry make-up looks, product shots and inspiration pics - they all make for a very beautiful Instagram feed. Tom Pecheux on @tompecheux A post shared by tompecheux (@tompecheux) on Jan 25, 2017 at 6:59am PST 
W hen he's not making up the likes of Mariah Carey (yes, really) for magazine covers, the leading make-up artist Tom Pecheux is creating beautiful make-up looks backstage. Right-hand man to Carine Roitfeld, Pecheux is the creative beauty mind for many leading shows and shoots. Lucia Pica on @picalucia A post shared by Lucia Pica (@luciapicaofficial) on Oct 27, 2015 at 7:54am PDT 
A s Chanel's global creative make-up and colour designer, Pica has a bold and beautiful Instagram account. As well as backstage snaps of models, expect some lust-worthy collections of Chanel products (yes, please) as well as interesting make-up tips and tricks. Lisa-Potter Dixon on @lisa_benefit A post shared by Lucia Pica (@luciapicaofficial) on Oct 27, 2015 at 7:54am PDT 
P otter-Dixon's Instagram feed is bright, colourful and a make-up junkie's dream. The head make-up and trend artist for Benefit Cosmetics, Potter-Dixon perfects bright eyes, glowy skin and show-stopping brows. Val Garland on @thevalgarland A post shared by ValGarland (@thevalgarland) on Sep 15, 2016 at 6:35am PDT 
V al's Instagram feed is the real deal: from inspiring make-up shoots and backstage videos, she's got it all covered. Follow Val for posts that will keep you glued for hours, and for her favourite make-up products marked with her famous hashtag #VALidate.
